title: Weekend picks for book lovers
text:
Weekend picks for book lovers Spend your weekend reading 'Lincoln in the Bardo.' Post to Facebook Weekend picks for book lovers Spend your weekend reading 'Lincoln in the Bardo.'  //usat.ly/2ltyq0H   Join the Nation's Conversation To   Weekend picks for book lovers Compiled by Jocelyn McClurg, USA TODAY 6:03 a.m. ET Feb. 18, 2017 'Lincoln in the Bardo' by George Saunders (Photo: Random House) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
What should you read this weekend? USA TODAY’s picks for book lovers include a debut novel that follows Abraham Lincoln as he makes a nighttime visit to his young son's grave. 
Lincoln in the Bardo by George Saunders; Random House, 343 pp.; fiction 
Lin-Manuel Miranda, what’s on your reading list? Lincoln in the Bardo , George Saunders’ exhilarating and theatrical novel about a grieving Abraham Lincoln, cries out for a stage adaptation. Who better than the creative genius behind Hamilton ? 
Told by a chorus of voices in a fast-paced, canto-like style, Bardo takes place on the February night in 1862 when the president has buried his favorite son, 11-year-old Willie, who died of typhoid fever. The setting: a cemetery not far from the White House, filled with restless souls stuck in limbo, a la Dante’s Inferno . 
Our three primary Dante-esque ghostly “guides” are Hans Vollman, felled by a beam before he could bed his much younger bride; Roger Bevins III, a young gay man who committed suicide; and the elderly and mysterious Rev. Everly Thomas. All, despite strange physical manifestations of their decaying states, are in denial and in no hurry to depart to the final great beyond. 
Joining them is a newcomer, young Willie. On this particular evening, a gaunt, shabby figure appears, sobbing; he goes to his son’s mausoleum, opens the coffin and embraces the boy he has lost. 
USA TODAY says **** out of four stars. “Brilliantly imagined…my early bet for a showering of literary awards.” Lincoln's trippy visit to son's grave in brilliant 'Bardo' 
Darling, I'm Going to Charlie by Maryse Wolinski; Atria/37 Ink, 144 pp.; non-fiction 
A memoir by the widow of cartoonist Georges Wolinski, among those murdered in Paris in the 2015 terrorist attack on Charlie Hebdo , the sacrilegious magazine. 
USA TODAY says ***½ stars. “Poignant… clear-eyed.” 'Charlie Hebdo' widow writes defiant memoir 
We’ll Always Have Casablanca by Noah Isenberg; Norton, 275 pp.; non-fiction 
In honor of Casablanca ’s 75th anniversary, an account of the making of the 1942 Warner Bros. classic and why it has endured as “Hollywood’s most beloved movie,” as the subtitle puts it. 
USA TODAY says **** stars. "Lively.” Why we love 'Casablanca,' 75 years later 
4 3 2 1 by Paul Auster; Henry Holt, 866 pp.; fiction 
This novel takes the life of one man, Archie Ferguson, born in 1947, and offers four alternative versions. 
USA TODAY says *** stars. “Give Auster full points for literary moxie… 4 3 2 1 must be applauded for its ambition.” One man, four lives, in Auster's '4 3 2 1' 
Stolen Beauty by Laurie Lico Albanese; Atria, 320 pp.; fiction 
Historical novel alternates between painter Gustav Klimt and his muse, Adele Bloch-Bauer, better known as the “Woman in Gold,” and Adele’s niece, Maria Altmann, during World War II. 
USA TODAY says *** stars. “Artfully weaves Adele’s story with Maria’s harrowing life under the Nazis.”
